section.title: Using Deployment Templates
section.para: The Deploy model for automated deployment is simple, yet flexible and extensible. Deployment can occur in a variety of operating environments, for example using virtual machines running on a local host, virtual machines running on remote or cloud-based hosts, physical machines managed by enterprise systems management systems, or unmanaged physical machines such as consumer desktops.

The model includes three deployment cases, test-install, test-update and publish. The first two cases were introduced previously in . The publish case will be introduced later under . Each case is represented by an element of the corresponding name in the definition.

Each deployment element supports a number of options, or sub-elements. These sub-elements are consistent across deployment elements, although the default behavior varies slightly between them in some instances. The sub-elements are described in detail in the chapter on Deployment Elements in the .
At a high level, deployment sub-elements serve to specify -

listitem.para: Deployment repository location, both file path and a web URL.
Client machine information including hostname, domain and password.
Installer options including boot options and a kickstart file.
Deployment specific config-rpms.
Scripts to delete, install, verify, and update client machines.

section.para: Many of these sub-elements can be reused across definitions, making them ideal candidates to be created as templates. In fact, because many of the sub-elements can be used in a mix-and-match fashion, a common practice is to save single sub-elements as individual templates. These individual templates can then be included directly in definitions, or nested within composite templates.
Deploy includes a number of deployment templates in the folder. In the previous section, we discussed one of these templates, the libvirt deployment template located at libvirt/deploy.xml.

This section will cover deployment templates in greater detail. It will also describe how you can customize deployment templates, or create your own, to meet the needs of individual deployment scenarios.

note.para: Do not modify templates in the folder. Deploy will overwrite your changes on subsequent updates. Instead, copy templates to another location and modify from there.

section.title: Exploring deployment templates
section.para: The libvirt deployment template provides an example for how Deploy can be used to deploy and maintain client systems. This particular template works by providing settings and scripts to accomplish the following:

listitem.para: Specify a domain, local, for client machines (domain).
Automate operating system installation using a kickstart file (kickstart).
Configure client machines to allow SSH access from the Deploy build machine (ssh-config.xml).
Determine whether the client machine should be reinstalled (test-triggers.xml).
Activate, delete, and install a virtual machine running on the Deploy build machine (virt-activate.xml, virt-delete.xml and virt-install.xml).
Verify the client machine installation (verify-install.xml).
Save information about client installation for future use (save-triggers.xml).
Update the client machine (update.xml).
Determine whether a new kernel has been installed and restart the system as necessary (check-kernel.xml).

section.para: The virt-deploy template, shown below, has very little content of its own and is largely composed by including sub-templates.
The sections discuss how you can reuse content from the libvirt deployment template and sub-templates, or provide alternate templates, to accommodate additional deployment scenarios.

section.title: Providing a custom kickstart
section.para: Kickstart files let you automate operating system installation by providing answers to language, network configuration, keyboard, file system configuration, mouse, timezone, root password and other selections.

The libvirt deployment template uses kickstart templates from the common deploy folder, deploy/common. The two templates are ks.xml and ks-post-ssh.xml. The first provides basic kickstart options. The second configures the client for ssh access. Contents of these templates are shown below.
The two files can be combined within a single kickstart element as follows:

The default ks.xml file uses macros (see the DDFR for information on deployment macros) to allow the hostname and root password to be filled in at Deploy runtime. Often, however, you will want to customize additional kickstart options such as timezone, or drive partitioning configuration. To do this, you will need to provide a custom kickstart element. This can be accomplished using several different methods. Perhaps the easiest method, however, is shown in the example test-install element below.

In this example, you start with a test-install element, add a password element and XInclude the libvirt deployment template. The XInclude statement is varies from ones you have used previously, however, in that it contains an xpointer attribute. Xpointer is used to include all elements from the file, except elements named kickstart. Next, you add a kickstart element. This element contains kickstart content to suit your needs; in the example below only the timezone has been changed. Finally, to the kickstart element you also include content from the ks-post-ssh.xml template.

informalexample.programlisting:
<test-install> <password>secret</password> <xi:include href="path/to/libvirt/deploy.xml" xpointer="xpointer(/*/*[name()!='kickstart'])"/> <kickstart> network --hostname %{fqdn} rootpw --iscrypted "%{crypt-password}" lang en_US zerombr bootloader --location=mbr clearpart --all --initlabel part / --fstype ext4 --size 1 --grow --asprimary part swap --recommended part /boot --fstype ext3 --size 512 --asprimary timezone America/Denver #change timezone to Denver auth --enablemd5 --enableshadow --enablecache selinux --enforcing reboot
%packages --nobase @core %{end-%{version}} <macro id='end-5'></macro> <macro id='end-6'>%end</macro> <xi:include href="/path/to/ks-ssh-post.xml" xpointer="xpointer(/*/node())"/> </kickstart> </test-install>

section.para: See the DDFR for more information on the kickstart element, including notes on several kickstart options to avoid when using kickstart in combination with Deploy.

section.title: Providing custom scripts
section.para: Deploy allows users to provide scripts for completing various deployment and maintenance actions. These scripts can be written in any shell scripting language.
The following example shows -

listitem.para: Including the poweroff script. The poweroff script can be used to shutdown a client following successful completion of the update script. This can be useful to conserve system resources between test runs. It does have a disadvantage, however, in that it increases the time required to complete test runs, as machines must be started before testing continues.
Providing a custom install script. In this case we are setting the virtual machine RAM at 2GB and the disk image size at 40GB.
Including all elements from the libvirt deployment template, except the check-kernel and install scripts. The check-kernel script is unnecessary since we are powering off the client after each run.

informalexample.programlisting: <test-install> <password>secret</password> <xi:include href="poweroff.xml"/> <script id='install' type='install'> #!/bin/bash virt-install --name %{fqdn} --ram 2000 \ --file /var/lib/libvirt/images/%{fqdn}.img \ --file-size 40 \ --location %{url} \ --extra-args "%{boot-options} ks=%{url}/ks.cfg"\ --noreboot </script> <xi:include href="path/to/libvirt/deploy.xml" xpointer="xpointer(/*/*[@id!='check-kernel' and @id!='virt-install'])"/> </test-install>

section.para: See the DDFR for complete information on deployment scripts, including the comes-before and comes-after attributes which allow ordering of script execution.

section.title: Installing a virtual machine to a remote host
section.para: The libvirt deployment template makes it easy to create, deploy and maintain virtual machines on the local Deploy build machine running a lib-virt compatible hypervisor (KVM). Your particular deployment scenario, however, may require you to work with virtual machines running on remote hosts with different hypervisors (e.g. VMware, Hyper-V and Amazon Web Services). To support this case, you will need to create a new composite template. This template will be similar to the libvirt deployment template. In the new template, you will need to adjust the domain element, and provide custom scripts to replace the activate, delete and install scripts.

For example, a composite template to create, deploy and maintain Amazon Machine Images (AMIs) for the Amazon Web Service (AWS), might look as follows, where ami-activate.xml, ami-delete.xml and ami-install.xml contain custom scripts for managing Amazon Machine Images:

informalexample.programlisting: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <xml xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude"> <!-- install and update an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) --> <domain>mydomain.com</domain> <kickstart> <xi:include href='../common/ks.xml' xpointer='xpointer(/*/node())'/> <xi:include href='../common/ks-post-ssh.xml' xpointer='xpointer(/*/node())'/> </kickstart> <xi:include href='../common/ssh-config.xml'/> <xi:include href='../common/test-triggers.xml'/> <xi:include href='ami-activate.xml'/> <xi:include href='ami-delete.xml'/> <xi:include href='ami-install.xml'/> <xi:include href='../common/verify-install.xml'/> <xi:include href='../common/save-triggers.xml'/> <xi:include href=’../common/update.xml’/> <xi:include href=’../common/check-kernel.xml’/> </xml>

section.title: Integrating with existing management solutions
section.para: Your organization may have an existing solution for managing system deployment and maintenance. You can enable integration with existing solutions using custom deployment scripts.

To deploy a single client using an existing deployment solution, the procedure is the same as discussed above under . Specifically, create a new deployment template with appropriate domain element, and custom activate, delete and install scripts.

Additionally, if your existing solution also manages system updates, you will either remove the update script from your composite template, or provide a custom update script that starts the appropriate update procedure on your management solution. If the custom script should execute on the Deploy build machine rather than on the installed client, be sure to set the update script's @ssh attribute to false. See the DDFR for more information on script attributes.
To deploy and update multiple clients based on the same definition, again you will create a new composite template. In this template, you will do the following:

listitem.para: Provide custom scripts that communication with the management solution to complete all desired actions
Disable SSH for all scripts using the ssh element
Provide a custom kickstart file that does not specify a hostname. The hostname will need to be set by dhcp to avoid assigning the same name to multiple systems.

section.para: See the example below.

informalexample.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <xml xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude">
<!-- install and update multiple systems using an external solution -->
install rootpw --iscrypted "%{crypt-password}" lang en_US zerombr bootloader --location=mbr clearpart --all --initlabel part / --fstype ext4 --size 1 --grow --asprimary part swap --recommended part /boot --fstype ext3 --size 512 --asprimary timezone America/Vancouver auth --enablemd5 --enableshadow --enablecache selinux --enforcing reboot
<ssh>false</ssh>
<xi:include href=’activate.xml’/> <xi:include href=’delete.xml’/> <xi:include href=’install.xml’/> <xi:include href=’update.xml’/> </xml>
